In Table 1, we analyze the performance of all methods under moderate (Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(0.1)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ0.1Dir(0.1)) to extreme (Dir(0.001Dir(0.001) heterogeneity. Interestingly, FedDiffÂ outperforms all other methods by a significant margin, from âˆ¼similar-to\sim5% to up to âˆ¼similar-to\sim20% in different scenarios.
In the case of CIFAR-10, which is the most complex of the datasets, we find that FedDiffÂ provides the most improvement. As discussed in our initial motivations (Section 3), we reason that the focus on sample quality and diversity that is provided by the DM objective enables much improved performance. Intuitively, this becomes increasingly evident in more complex settings. To verify this observation, we conduct a comparative analysis of generated samples produced by FedCVAE and our FedDiffÂ approach, illustrated in Figure 2. The discernible disparity is evident, with the samples generated by our method exhibiting significantly enhanced sharpness and overall quality.

As a fixed-size dataset is used in all experiments, increasing the number of clients also decreases the number of samples per client. We find that the SOTA discriminative approaches quickly degrade as the data is distributed across more clients. On the contrary, our FedDiffÂ maintains strong performance in all settings.

To further explore the efficacy of our method, we also examine resource factors, including FLOPs and parameter count, for each method deployed on a single client.
Notably, our FedDiffÂ approach consistently delivers superior accuracy with comparable computational resources to other methods. We extend this assessment to a reduced model size (FedDiffs in Table 3), reaffirming its strong performance relative to alternative methods. This analysis underscores the effectiveness of FedDiff, even when deployed on hardware with modest computational capabilities.

Differential privacy is the widely accepted standard for ensuring privacy of a model, as it offers a provable guarantee of privacy [1, 8, 9, 7, 11]. Utilizing (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta) differential privacy during model training guarantees comprehensive privacy protection, encompassing not only the modelâ€™s parameters and activations, but also extending to all subsequent downstream operations such as inferences, fine-tuning, and distillation. It is important to note that a model trained under (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta) DP safeguards the privacy of every training sample, regardless of its qualities or uniqueness [34].
Specifically, we train all approaches under (Ïµ,Î´italic-Ïµğ›¿\epsilon,\delta) DP at the clients for various privacy levels of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon = 50, 25, and 10, with Î´=10â€‹eâˆ’5ğ›¿10superscriptğ‘’5\delta=10e^{-5}, C=10ğ¶10C=10, and Î±=0.01ğ›¼0.01\alpha=0.01. Lower Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon values correspond to a tighter privacy budget, and the stated budget is for the entire training of each local model. We employ the Opacus [34] library for implementing DP. Further DP training details are provided in Supplementary Material, along with additional Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon experiment. We present the results for all approaches in Table 4.

In Figure 5, we show the results of applying our FMF approach with FedDiffÂ for the same overall DP budgets as Table 4. FMF is particularly effective in the most difficult scenarios, helping to mitigate the performance drop in harsh FL environments. For example, FMF provides over 3.5% and 2% improvements with PathMNIST and CIFAR-10 in the challenging Ïµ=10italic-Ïµ10\epsilon=10 setting. Overall, FMF is a simple way to boost performance in one-shot FL under DP.

To demonstrate the feasibility of FedDiffÂ under more stringent budget constraints, we conduct an experiment with an even tighter privacy budget of Ïµ=1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon=1 in Table 5. Despite facing such stringent privacy constraints, FedDiffÂ maintains a higher level of performance at Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon = 1 than all other methods in Table 4 of the main paper at Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon = 50.
